utterances: Thank you.

I'm away on vacation for the next couple of weeks.
Michel Martin will be in this chair.
I'm Neal Conan, National Public Radio News in Washington.
From NPR News in Washington, I'm Michelle Martin, and this is TALK OF THE NATION.
As the men go off to war, and it's still mostly men, they are the women waving goodbye, and to outsiders, anyway, their ability to cope is the stuff of legend.

What is frustrating is hearing the crybabies.

It's TALK OF THE NATION.
First the news.
Mm hmm.
And why is that so unusual?
Why was that such a discovery to understand that the dolphins could recognize a synthetic whistle?
I would think, you know, if I call someone's name and someone else calls someone's name, don't we both recognize the name no matter who's calling it, even if a speaker were calling it?
Yes, well, that's true for us, but interestingly, really most other animals that have been studied, if not all, do not use distinctive sounds to refer to other individual animals.

Instead they tend to produce sort of a species specific vocal repertoire, and then they have individual variability in how they say sounds, just the way, again, you know, your voice sounds different from someone else's voice, and that's how animals recognize one another, not through a distinctive signal that is essentially a name.
Mm hmm.
Now, what does this tell us about the way that dolphins communicate?
Does it mean that if they have names for each other, they may have a language also?

Well, I think it's definitely too early to say that this would be anything, part of a language, but it is an important component of language, to be able to communicate referentially, in other words, to use arbitrary signals to refer to something, and that's what our words are like, and in this case dolphins are using an arbitrary whistle sound to refer to another dolphin, and since they learn these signals, it also shows that they're capable of acquiring new signals, which is, of course, another important aspect of language as well.
Now, which part of the whistle do they recognize?
Do they recognize the frequency or is there a - if we take it apart, could we hear little parts of it that have maybe syllables in it?
You know what I'm talking about?
Yeah.
Well, what they seem to be cuing in on is really what we call the contour, which is a pattern of frequency changes over time.
And I know you probably didn't pick up on too much of it because they're kind of high frequency and fast, and so we tend to look at them visually on the computer.
But that's what they're cuing in on, and they do vary aspects of it and sometimes repeat certain components of the whistle.
Mm hmm.
And we, one possibility is that when they vary aspects of the whistle, it may be conveying additional information sort of superimposed on the identity information.
Mm hmm.
We have three more of the natural whistles.
Let's hear them and see how we can pick on that, those cues you talked about.
(Soundbite of dolphin whistles)
Well, I hope the tweeters are working fine because they were very high frequencies.
Yeah.
Where were they?

Those are anywhere probably from about maybe six to 20 kilohertz, and our upper frequency hearing pretty much cuts off at 20 or lower, depending our age, so it's pretty hard to listen to those, to get a lot of the variability in them by listening.
Do those frequencies travel better in water?
Is that why they have them so high up there?
Well, they, all sound travels better in water than in air, but they don't travel further, for example, than low frequency sounds.
Those can travel further than dolphin whistles, but these are probably used to fairly close-ranged communication.
Mm hmm.
So where do you go from here with research like this?
Well, there's a lot...
What would you like to know next?

Yeah, well, there's a lot of different places we can look at, but one thing that's very interesting about dolphins is that they do imitate one another's signature whistles, in addition to producing their own.

So trying to understand how that might function in their natural communication system would be really fun and interesting and as well as understanding how some of the other sounds that they produce function.
They produce whistles other than their signature whistles, and there's very little known about that.
Yeah, the sounds they make at...
And also, I guess, yeah...
The sounds they make at the aquariums and things, are those just for us?
Yes, those are.
Those are completely trained.
They don't open their mouths in the wild when they make sounds.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
Because that sounded, you're right, it sounded nothing like these.
And thank you for clearing that up.
And thank you for taking time to be with us, doctor.
You're welcome.
Thanks for inviting me.
Dr.
Laela Sayigh is a visiting investigator at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute in Woods Hole, Massachusetts.
She's also a research associate professor at the University of North Carolina in Wilmington.
And one of the outstanding mysteries of last week's Brussels attacks is the identity of the man in a hat.
That's the third man caught on video pushing a cart alongside two suicide bombers at the Brussels airport.
The only person police have arrested and charged in the bombings so far has also been released because of lack of evidence.
And for a general update on what's going on in Brussels, we reached NPR's counterterrorism correspondent Dina Temple-Raston.
She is in Brussels.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Good morning.
Now, let's start with the release of this suspect.
Tell us more about him and why he was released exactly.

So Kimberly Rios and her colleague Azim Shariff, Steve, along with their grad students - they started thinking - what's the effect of the stereotype that Christians in the United States have a problem with science?

And they asked - is it possible that stereotype threat, this time applied to a majority group - American Christians - might stereotype threat explain data that shows that Christians are often outperformed in science by non-Christians?

Well, this man was picked up just after - sorry - this is the man that police had thought was the mysterious third man captured on security footage, as you said - the one wearing the hat and the glasses and the light-colored coat.
And he allegedly ran from the airport shortly after the two suicide bombers had exploded their suicide vests.
And police picked up a citizen journalist named Faycal Cheffou.
And they thought he was in fact that third man, the man in the hat.
He was arrested right outside the federal prosecutor's office.
And he was charged with terrorism offenses.
But now a judge has released him saying there's not enough evidence to hold him.
And, to be honest, he doesn't really fit the profile of an ISIS operative.
As far as we know he has no connection to the group or to the men that police are looking for who might have been part of this plot.
And why were the authorities so sure he was involved?
Well, that was because a taxi driver who had driven the bombers to the airport picked him out of a lineup and said this looked like the third man.

I mean, this is definitely a setback for investigators as the three other people identified as directly involved in the bombings - the Bakraoui brothers and the suspected bomb-maker - they're all dead.
And that leaves Belgium worrying about who might be still out there waiting for an attack - so worried in fact that U.S.
sources tell us that the Belgians have provided copies of hard drives, of computers they have found and phones related to the attack.
They have provided those to the FBI hoping they can help with the investigation.
Now, the Belgians have identified other suspects.
Is that correct?
They have identified some, but we hear from sources in the U.S.
that the only one that they think they actually have a name to is this mysterious third man that you saw in the surveillance video.
The Belgians have also released for the first time that surveillance video showing this third man pushing the luggage cart, as you say.
And they are hoping that the public will be able to identify him and provide some clues.
Right now we don't know who it is that they are looking for specifically.
The U.S.
hasn't released the name, and neither have the Belgians.
And we just have about a minute here.
The Brussels airport, where the first attack took place, that is still closed?
That's still closed.
All flights are still canceled.
Officials are still trying to determine whether or not it's structurally sound after the bombings.
They haven't said when it will be reopened.
So people right now who are booked to fly out of Brussels are being rerouted.

Well, certainly more to come there in Brussels.
